prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext: Separate procedures for handling tag-along actions are necessary and appropriate for a number of reasons. First, the Panel needs a streamlined procedure for handling these actions because the parties frequently have no objection at all to the tag-along action being transferred to the district where actions have previously been transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings. Second, even if there is an objection to transfer, the Panel does not require extensive new information in order to make the transfer decision. Third, the fact that the Panel has previously transferred similar cases may be news to the attorneys in the tag-along case, and the Panel needs to provide them useful information so that they may inform themselves about transfer.

To lawyers involved in pending cases when transfer by the Panel is first considered, transfer is not a difficult problem. Each party starts at essentially the same point and is able to assimilate information concerning the wisdom of transfer, the appropriateness of it under the statute, and the selection of a transferee judge at essentially the same time as the other parties in the cases. To a lawyer who filed a single, simple case in state court and who is just coming to grips with the removal of the case to federal court by the defendant, receipt of a conditional transfer order transferring the case across the country may be a complete shock.[1] It may be equally shocking to the defendant who thought removing the case to federal court was the ultimate in sophisticated motion practice and a coup for the client for whatever tactical reason. In fact, many lawyers are introduced to the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation in this fashion, not by carefully researching the Panel's existence and power and then preparing a motion for transfer.

Tag-along actions are a normal and expected part of Panel practice. Indeed, the Panel has transferred cases, in part, because of the likelihood that additional actions would be filed and because transfer would provide a “ready forum” for newly filed actions.[2]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
For an example of a case where this occurred, see In re Air Crash Disaster at Juneau, Alaska, on September 4, 1971, 360 F. Supp. 1406 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
See In re Air Crash Disaster at Stapleton Intern. Airport in Denver, Colo., on August 7, 1975, 447 F. Supp. 1071, 1072 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
